We are an empowerment platform connecting the worlds of business and technology
Apr 15

HACKERStories — Inside View: Co-Founder Marc Seitz on The Empowerment Platform

HACKERStories dishes the Inside View on Hackerbay Co-Founder and CTO, Marc Seitz, and what it means to him, and the company, to be an Empowerment Platform.

Before founding Hackerbay, Seitz studied Economics in Hong Kong, followed by Physics in Munich. Despite enjoying it, his initial career in Finance didn’t prove challenging enough, so he started the transition into software development out of sheer curiosity and desire to learn. In coding, he found a totally new arena with limitless growth potential where the limits to what he could create were non-existent, and hasn’t looked back since.

What sparked your interest in building technology?

I began coding because I couldn’t. My ignorance was my motivation. I have definitely learnt a lot over the past few years, but I wouldn’t say that I am particularly proud of my achievements. For me, the beauty of Hacker Culture is that there is no cap on your potential or limit to what you can create. If there are infinite possibilities, I guess that means you can never reach the ‘top’, because it technically doesn’t exist… but that’s what keeps me going.

When did software development start becoming a big part of your life?

I was still at University when I started to code- around 3 years ago. At one point, I attended three Hackathons in three different cities on three consecutive weekends, all whilst attending class during the week. I built a computer from scratch in the library. That was when I realised that what I was doing wasn’t normal, but I loved it. Before I knew it, I was flying to San Francisco to compete in Hackathons– and winning them. Concierge apps were hot in 2015, so I decided to make one for Hackathons. I did it in two days, and as I didn’t have an iPhone myself, I deployed the app at the Apple Store in Munich instead. My life had become unpredictable in a great way.

How did a personal interest in coding turn into a business idea?

Hackers are driven by the endless need to learn, build and improve, so it makes sense that the birth of Hackerbay came from a moment of standstill. I attended a Hackathon in London in 2016 and had to leave after 10 hours because it just didn’t feel new anymore. So instead of stopping, we changed track and built a company out of the expertise and diverse network that we had been gathering for the past few years, and it’s only getting stronger.

Hackerbay is an empowerment platform connecting the worlds of business and technology.

So how are exactly are you making this connection?

Most specifically, Hackerbay connects corporations with the best software engineers in the world. Neither entity has had the opportunity to connect with the other before because the process isn’t as easy as ordering an Uber, for example. We have become too used to easy, transactional button-pushing and it’s stunting the potential to create new and valuable relationships. On top of that, hackers don’t usually like to be compromised on the software they build­. Overall there’s a disconnect between two very different mentalities that we are trying to resolve, in order to come up with unique solutions. It is a process of mutual empowerment, because once the connection is made, both sides can only benefit in a very positive way.

We transfer the digital knowledge (or SVIs) of our talented network of hackers to the client. Not only are we amongst the fastest in rapid-prototyping in the global technology space, but we want to and know how to transfer that to corporate culture.

What does ‘empowerment platform’ mean?

We see it as a dynamic, collaborative space which reveals opportunity windows in the talent of hackers and the potential of corporations. At Hackerbay, we associate the word ‘empowerment’ with opportunity, in all senses of the word. In theory, it is the opportunity to change the corporate and digital worlds by uniting them. In practise, we are creating employment opportunities for talented developers to demonstrate their ability- which in turn gives corporations the opportunity evolve, grow and prosper. This is mutual empowerment- one of our main aims as a company.

You are not only empowering businesses, but hackers as individuals. Why do you think that’s important?

To be honest, they are friends of ours, and we want their talent to be recognised. But most importantly, if they get better at what they do and they have the opportunity to demonstrate what they are capable of, they will end up being the backbone of our new economy. They have the capacity to ‘disrupt’ in the sense of adapting to a new frame of mind and attitude.

Since most of them are self-taught, they remain outside of conventional education and professional systems. They are constantly improving themselves and that is not necessarily possible in a conventional working environment- we think that corporate culture no longer has any space for experimentation. As a result, hackers are mostly freelance, which means that they can be objective in terms of the structure of our economy and corporate habits. If you think of someone who works in a bank- they are so within the system that they cannot see a way to change it/they know no different. These guys are floating on the outside looking down and can see the bigger picture.

What about the Empowerment Platform is unique? Why do you think it has not been developed before?

Well for one, it’s just very difficult. You are bringing together two different mind-sets that ordinarily will clash. You are the mediator between them, which means you have to fully understand both mind-sets, which we do. It’s arbitration- you are just the infrastructure. You are neither the person that gains the recognition (hackers) or the person who gains competitive edge in software and ultimately, capital (businesses).

The irony is that we are not technically empowered in the same way that our clients or hackers are- we are not making new gains or developments per se. However, we are empowered in a different sense; through the notion that we are finally bringing the skills of these intellectuals to light and making a change for the better for both them and the client.

Submitting the blueprint to the Empowerment Platform results in the ultimate goal of Digital Evolution; the point where the business in question has adapted to thrive in a high-tech environment…

Can you talk more about Digital Evolution?

Being open to a new business model for companies sounds simple, but it is quite unconventional and revolutionary. Not shying away from using best practises, because it’s nowadays very rare that when you build something from scratch that it will be the best of its kind. Everything has been done, so chances are, the best practise for you to use is already out there. For some reason companies usually ignore this and prefer to be stubborn, which means they are missing out on true development purely because they feel the need to ‘own’ things and be pioneers. The reality is that you can much more easily be a pioneer by assembling existing tools in a new and unique way; and that is what coding is.

Think about it like this: if you’re building a house, you use the best materials out there- ones that are already available. You don’t decide to make your bricks from scratch because you know that you probably would do a bad job in comparison to what already exists. And also- it would be a huge effort and waste of time, and that’s the alteration that needs to be made in the corporate mind-set)/

In a more practical sense however, digital evolution is setting up your workforce so that it is more horizontally integrated. In other words, being flexible to changes within the structure of their own business or industry. Especially in Germany, everyone is stuck in being a specialist so they cannot adapt and change quickly. They have dedicated their lives to becoming that specialist that they have become too rigid in their ways and totally inflexible to change- and ironically, that is their downfall. In trying to be market leaders in a specialised and linear sense, they are actually undergoing self-sabotage. And that is what we want to try and prevent. There is competiton in the American market, especially, which has adopted this more free-floating or failing-forward attitude, and again and again they are annihilating competition because they are fluid and adaptable, and open to evolution. It is time for European companies to catch up.

Why do you think that it is important for companies to reach Digital Evolution?

Honestly, so they don’t just die. It will enhance market competition which is obviously healthy, and internally, they will become more streamlined with their products and processes- the outcome of which is efficiency.

Also, no one considers the impact of individuals in companies in regards to technological development; what about the CEOs of these companies that we want to transform? Our hope is that if they see the successes that technology can empower them with, their personal mind-sets will be altered to new possibilities in general via our methodology, experience with the Empowerment platform and Hacker Culture).

Can you describe the ins-and-outs of what’s happening in the Empowerment Platform?

The Hacker Framework, or THF, is our unique methodology of software development made up of 5 phases; Adapt, Design, Build, Launch and Evolve. These phases are spread of 50 Steps in order to take an idea or a problem and turn it into a fully successful product for the client, set to thrive in the digital environment of today. The Empowerment Platform is specifically made up of phases 3 and 4: Build and Launch.

In terms of how the EP operates internally, we get the team in place for any specific project, basing our assessment and preparation on the requirements we gather from the personalized blueprint- a feature of the first phase of The Hacker Framework. We designed a unique algorithm based on 32 criteria by which we assess each individual hacker in the network, (such as availability, years of experience, propensity for self-improvement, programming languages…), and when the blueprint is submitted into the platform, it is processed via this algorithm to identify the exact hackers for each task. This is one of the ways that we can totally ensure the quality of our software, and eliminate risk for both client and developer.

We then take the requirements of the blueprint and set up a version control code repository so that the teams of developers can work individually on the same code base (like a Google doc for apps). Then, we split up the tasks (front-end, back-end, gathering data) and distribute them between the team of developers that are identified for each client project via the algorithm. This benefits us most prolifically in the fact that the best developers in the world for the project may be continents apart- but we connect them via this singular platform to enable the best talent to collaborate and produce top quality software.

Any last words on the Empowerment Platform?

Just that we hope our Empowerment Platform portrays how passionate about finding the niche group which will embrace the wave of new technology, and most importantly the hackers themselves. This has been clearly very successful in Silicon Valley, and now we want to extract that attitude and inject it into the corporate landscape in a wider sense. We want to eliminate the negative connotation that hackers are associated with because it’s purely incorrect. There’s a huge, untapped resource of technological intellect just sitting out there waiting to be utilized- and we just want to see that happen!
